data.text: @ScornflakeGrrrl That's one way to do it I guess! 🤣

@basilbrushoff Tbh I reset my password every time I need to access something because I can never remember them. That together with tfa feels fairly safe. Biggest thread is still phishing/social engineering
@JV8P Awesome. Also loving these password books that Amazon sells https://t.co/QVrG8pz81r

@ScornflakeGrrrl Yeah, true. Context is everything. Also I agree with the other commenter that a fixed strong password is better than a series of weaker ones. I tweak it based on use case but I think my password generator for online use is about 15 characters, A-Z/a-z/0-9/symbols.

@ScornflakeGrrrl A contact at HMRC once had to visit a high street accountancy practice whose login credentials had been compromised to discuss the incident/offer guidance.
The password was on a whiteboard which was visible through a window from the (busy) pavement as he approached the building.
@basilbrushoff If it was in a room where strangers wouldn’t be left alone in to be seen I agree with you. But I have been audited for 27001 so much I tend to twitch quite quickly now

@ScornflakeGrrrl Honestly I don't even hate it. Generally once someone has physical access to a machine (nearly) all bets are off anyway.

Of course I'd like more people/services to use stronger authentication methods like password managers or, better, private key authentication, but... 🤷‍♂️

@ScornflakeGrrrl One day, people will learn that a good password is better than one you have to change every day. I'm 99% certain daily/weekly/monthly passwords either have the date or an increasing number as the only thing that changes
